issue.title: Include en and en-US FTL files in locale/
issue.body:
There's been some discussion lately on whether or not we _want_ to rely purely on fallback text for en/en-US users, as we have been since setting Fluent up in FxA as far as I know. We had a recent bug show us that English/US users were actually very likely seeing `en-GB` locales (see [more info here](https://github.com/mozilla/fxa/pull/12861#issuecomment-1125440236)), and since changing the Fluent strategy to be more precise in its matching, our fallback text is showing as expected. However, we keep uncovering instances where we haven't supplied fallback text, which has created several fairly severe (from a UI point of view) bugs, the newest few coming up today.

While discussions on how we handle fallback text are still ongoing and at the time of writing we want to always supply fallback text, the team seems to agree on at least on including our English FTL files in the `locale` directory for consistency, and I believe we should go ahead and do this now to prevent any further "fallback text missing" surprises when we push to production.

comment.body:
> I would copy all the FTL files to en  and see if that solves the issue with fallback on your side, possibly drop en_US in the process.

Can we safely remove en_US in this PR, or does that need changes in FxA?

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -125,4 +120,17 @@ cp -r $L10N_DIR/locale/fy_NL/* $L10N_DIR/locale/fy
 sed -i'' -e 's/Language: fy_NL/Language: fy/g' "$L10N_DIR/locale/fy/LC_MESSAGES/client.po"
 sed -i'' -e 's/Language: fy_NL/Language: fy/g' "$L10N_DIR/locale/fy/LC_MESSAGES/server.po"
 
+# Fluent extraction
+cp $PAYMENTS_DIR/public/locales/en-US/*.ftl $L10N_DIR/locale/templates
+cp $SETTINGS_DIR/public/locales/en-US/*.ftl $L10N_DIR/locale/templates
+cp $MAILER_DIR/public/locales/en/*.ftl $L10N_DIR/locale/templates
+
+# Pontoon will read from the "templates" directory but we must copy the FTL files
+# into "en" to ensure users with English will always see good fallback text.
+# We can remove the "templates" directory once we are off of gettext entirely -
+# then, Pontoon will read from the "en" directory.
+cp $PAYMENTS_DIR/public/locales/en-US/*.ftl $L10N_DIR/locale/en
+cp $SETTINGS_DIR/public/locales/en-US/*.ftl $L10N_DIR/locale/en
+cp $MAILER_DIR/public/locales/en/*.ftl $L10N_DIR/locale/en
comment.body:
Is there a reason not to use `cp $L10N_DIR/locale/templates/*.ftl $L10N_DIR/locale/en` vs 3 commands?

The advantage is that this line will remain the same, no matter if one of the packages change locale code later.

pull_request.title: Refactor editor state management
pull_request.body:
This PR effectively rewrites much of the internals of the editor. Mostly the changes are below the surface, but some aspects are user-visible. The primary intent of this series of changes is to make state management clearer; less imperative and more reactive.

In the big picture, the redux `EditorState` and its associated actions are split into multiple React Contexts:

#### `EditorData`
- `EditorState.translation` → `EditorData.value`
- `EditorState.initialTranslation` → `EditorData.initial`
- `EditorState.isRunningRequest` → `EditorData.busy`
- `EditorState.machinerySources` → `EditorData.machinery.sources`
- `EditorState.machineryTranslation` → `EditorData.machinery.translation`
- `useForceSource()` → `EditorData.view`: `'simple' | 'rich' | 'source'`
- new: `EditorData.activeInput`: `MutableRefObject<HTMLTextAreaElement>`
- new: `EditorData.format`: `'simple' | 'ftl'`

#### `EditorActions`
Separated from `EditorData` as these in general do not need to be rebuilt during the application's lifetime.
- `startUpdateTranslation()` → `EditorActions.setEditorBusy(busy)`
- `endUpdateTranslation()` → `EditorActions.setEditorBusy(busy)`
- `updateMachinerySources(machinerySources, machineryTranslation)` & `useCopyMachineryTranslation()` & `useCopyOtherLocaleTranslation()` → `EditorActions.setEditorFromMachinery(value, sources)`
- `updateSelection(content, changeSource)` & `useAddTextToTranslation()` → `EditorActions.setEditorSelection(content)`
- `updateTranslation(translation, changeSource)` & `useUpdateTranslation()` → `EditorActions.setEditorFromInput(value)`
- `useForceSource()` → `EditorActions.toggleFtlView()`
- `useReplaceSelectionContent()` → `EditorActions.setEditorFromHistory(value)`

### `FailedChecksData`
- `EditorState.errors` → `FailedChecksData.errors`
- `EditorState.warnings` → `FailedChecksData.warnings`
- `EditorState.source` → `FailedChecksData.source`
- `updateFailedChecks(failedChecks, source)` → `FailedChecksData.setFailedChecks(data, source)`
- `resetFailedChecks()` → `FailedChecksData.resetFailedChecks()`

### `HelperSelection`
- `EditorState.selectedHelperElementIndex` → `HelperSelection.element`
- `EditorState.selectedHelperTabIndex` → `HelperSelection.tab`
- `selectHelperElementIndex(index)` → `HelperSelection.setElement(element)`
- `selectHelperTabIndex(index)` → `HelperSelection.setTab(element)`

### Factored out
These are no longer needed
- `EditorState.changeSource`
- `EditorState.selectionReplacementContent`
- `setInitialTranslation(translation)`
- `resetEditor()`
- `resetHelperElementIndex()`
- `resetSelection()`

The fundamental change here is perhaps best illustrated by the dropped reset actions; those are replaced by `useEffect()` calls in the respective providers which are automatically triggered when their dependencies change. Moving the state management to these new React Contexts allows for code otherwise to have far fewer side effects, and for far less state to be managed through listeners attached to components much further in the tree.

This allows for the following components to all be merged into a single `Editor` component:
- `EditorSelector`
- `FluentEditor`
- `GenericEditor`
- `RichEditor`
- `SimpleEditor`
- `SourceEditor`

To manage this refactor, it turned out to be necessary to also systematize the parsing and serialization of Fluent messages. To that end, a pair of functions `parseEntry(source)` and `serializeEntry(entry)` function is provided as wrappers around `FluentParser`, `FluentSerializer` and the Fluent `Transformer`:
- All messages are flattened during parsing, and the `flattenMessage()` function is dropped.
- Empty messages, attributes and variants are represented by empty string literals `{ "" }` in the source.
- It should be noted that for efficiency, `serializeEntry(entry)` will modify rather than clone its `entry` argument; a great majority of its call sites will in any case immediately discard the original entry.

The second of these changes is visible to users, as the string literals may now show up in the "source" view. This is required to allow for e.g. the "clear" action to now produce actually valid and parsable Fluent. As a benefit of doing so, it should now no longer be as common to be able to get the editor to render as empty. Another related change is that even in the "source" view, clearing the message will still leave it with the key and structure of the original.

I've been putting off this changeset for a while, but it turns out to be pretty much necessary for properly resolving #2050, which will need to add yet another async pathway for modifying the editor contents. I tried doing so under the current/previous editor state management system, but that was trending towards making an already-slightly-hacky system even more so, and making it much more difficult to reason about the system state.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -181,3 +181,48 @@ def wrapper(request, *args, **kw):
         return response
 
     return wrapper
+
+
+def api_authentication(f):
+    """Allows API authentication to be used by this django view. Standard auth will
+    already have been attempted by this point so api auth will only be tried for
+    anonymous (unauthenticated) requests."""
+
+    from rest_framework import exceptions as drf_exceptions
+    from rest_framework.settings import api_settings
+    from rest_framework.views import exception_handler as drf_exception_handler
+
+    from olympia.api.authentication import (
+        get_authorization_header,
+        SessionIDAuthentication,
+        JWTKeyAuthentication,
+    )
+
+    @functools.wraps(f)
+    def wrapper(request, *args, **kw):
+        if request.user.is_anonymous and get_authorization_header(request):
+            # if user isn't authenticated with standard auth, try the API auth methods
+            try:
+                for api_auth in (SessionIDAuthentication, JWTKeyAuthentication):
+                    api_auth = api_auth()
+                    result = api_auth.authenticate(request)
+                    if result:
+                        request.user, _ = result
+                        break
+            except drf_exceptions.AuthenticationFailed as exc:
+                # We have to set some props DRF would usually set in the APIView
comment.body: yes, the `Response` that the exception handler generates needs/expects those properties to render the json response.

pull_request.title: add api auth to download_file view
add api auth to download_file view

issue.title: `./manage.py process_emails_from_sqs` has increasing memory usage when not doing work
issue.body:
An email task in stage had increasing memory usage despite not processing any emails:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/286017/169080559-f5cffc87-4329-4b4e-bda2-225052dcb7f9.png)

The k8s deployment has an upper memory limit, and will kill the email task when it exceeds the memory budget and there is memory pressure.

Local testing with `traceback` shows that the `botocore/hooks.py` file appears to be increasing, but that it stays steady if `gc.collect()` is run periodically.

+        SessionIDAuthentication,
+        JWTKeyAuthentication,
+    )
+
+    @functools.wraps(f)
+    def wrapper(request, *args, **kw):
+        if request.user.is_anonymous and get_authorization_header(request):
+            # if user isn't authenticated with standard auth, try the API auth methods
+            try:
+                for api_auth in (SessionIDAuthentication, JWTKeyAuthentication):
+                    api_auth = api_auth()
+                    result = api_auth.authenticate(request)
+                    if result:
+                        request.user, _ = result
+                        break
+            except drf_exceptions.AuthenticationFailed as exc:
+                # We have to set some props DRF would usually set in the APIView
comment.body: the comment or setting those properties?

pull_request.title: add api auth to download_file view

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -181,3 +181,48 @@ def wrapper(request, *args, **kw):
         return response
 
     return wrapper
+
+
+def api_authentication(f):
+    """Allows API authentication to be used by this django view. Standard auth will
+    already have been attempted by this point so api auth will only be tried for
+    anonymous (unauthenticated) requests."""
+
+    from rest_framework import exceptions as drf_exceptions
+    from rest_framework.settings import api_settings
+    from rest_framework.views import exception_handler as drf_exception_handler
+
+    from olympia.api.authentication import (
+        get_authorization_header,
+        SessionIDAuthentication,
+        JWTKeyAuthentication,
+    )
+
+    @functools.wraps(f)
+    def wrapper(request, *args, **kw):
+        if request.user.is_anonymous and get_authorization_header(request):
+            # if user isn't authenticated with standard auth, try the API auth methods
+            try:
+                for api_auth in (SessionIDAuthentication, JWTKeyAuthentication):
+                    api_auth = api_auth()
+                    result = api_auth.authenticate(request)
+                    if result:
+                        request.user, _ = result
+                        break
+            except drf_exceptions.AuthenticationFailed as exc:
+                # We have to set some props DRF would usually set in the APIView

issue.body:
In which [~accountid:60482ee0b2ea1201159d2194] will discuss:

* What is it?
* How does it work?
* What needs to be done?

┆Issue is synchronized with this [Jira Task](https://mozilla-hub.atlassian.net/browse/FXA-5089)

comment.body:
➤ Bianca Danforth commented:

Some additional topics requested:

  * Why is the Support Form hosted on the content server?
  * What are some bugs we’ve had with the Support Form and why?
  * What would you change about how the Support Form is implemented?
  * How do we develop the Support Form locally? (I don’t see anything in the fxa-content-server’s README that explicitly addresses this.)
